content: I recently got a Tesla — these are my first thoughts. Jerry WeiBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingApr 1 Teslas are known for being technologically sophisticated, along with being one of the most recognizable electric cars out there. I’m a tech-savvy guy, and so I got the Mid-Range Tesla Model 3 with Enhanced Autopilot. Here’s what I think about it.  Delivery. In my opinion, one of the coolest things about buying a Tesla is seeing it pull up to your house. It’s a really sleek car, and it’s soooo quiet (I thought I had gone deaf!). The lack of an engine really goes a long way and makes it so much cooler as it rolls in. The delivery went smoothly; a Tesla sales representative helped me out with getting to know the car. Looks. Honestly, this car looks so nice. The panoramic glass roof with UV protection is gorgeous, the hidden door handles are subtle touches, the wheels are pretty cool, and the curved design is beautiful. 10/10. Regenerative braking. One of the more difficult elements to get used to is the regenerative braking. Teslas use this feature to regenerate some battery using the momentum of your car. Essentially, when you let go of the accelerator, the car slows down as if you had lightly hit the brakes. At first, I thought this was a super weird feature, and it was definitely hard to get used to. When I got used to it though, it turns out it’s really convenient. Regenerative braking lets you use one pedal to drive, and it really goes easy on your legs. Definitely one of my favorite features. Autopilot. Some people don’t get enhanced autopilot on their Teslas, which doesn’t really make sense to me since that’s one of the most defining aspects of Teslas. Anyway, this feature is super cool and really good at making commutes less annoying. I love driving, but traffic annoys even me! Activating Autopilot in traffic for some reason makes it such a better drive — you don’t have to think too hard about accelerating and braking every 3 seconds because the Tesla does it for you. Protects your sanity. In terms of using it in non-traffic scenarios, I find that it brakes a little later than I like. That being said, it never rear-ends another car, so maybe I just like braking early.  Sensors and Cameras. Teslas sport a huge array of cameras and sensors and displays the information for you on the screen. It detects lanes, shows the cars around you, and can record crashes. This lets it have Forward Collision Warning, where it beeps if you’re approaching a car in front of you very quickly. It also has Automatic Emergency Braking as a final resort, braking hard to try to avoid rear-ending someone. I haven’t had to use Automatic Emergency Braking yet, and there haven’t been any real cases where I need Forward Collision Warning, but it has activated when I’ve gotten close to parked car in my neighborhood (that I wasn’t going to hit on my current path). Tesla App. This is an awesome design. As I said, I’m a tech-savvy guy, so being able to control a car with my phone is unbelievable. I can control the music, lock/unlock the car, turn on/off the climate, and so much more all from my phone! The app also allows for keyless driving, or you can set up your phone to be a key. No more forgetting your key and having to run back to grab it. Over-the-air Software Updates. This is another really nice feature of the Tesla. Instead of having to get a new car to get the new features, Teslas just download the features when connected to Wi-Fi. So this definitely cool in theory, but I’m having trouble getting software updates — I received the Sentry Mode update about a month after it started being released, and I haven’t gotten any of the more recent updates yet. Adding a button to manually check for updates would be something that Tesla can look into.  Quality-Of-Life Features. There are a variety of other fantastic details that make life so much easier for me. Here are just some of the cool features: Automatically opens your garage door when you get leave or approach your house.Driver profiles — Teslas automatically move the seat back to easily let you inside and it’s quite easy to select and change a driver profile.Will look in the blind spot for you when you try to make a lane change; the lane will appear red on the screen if there’s a car there.Automatic windshield wipers will adjust speed based on how heavy the precipitation is.Automatic high-beam lights will turn on high-beam for you.Sentry Mode monitors your car when it’s parked and records anyone who damages it, though you have to manually turn it on every time.Automatic parking brakes will set the parking brake for you when you park and disengage it when you move.Allows you to play Atari on the touchscreen when you’re waiting to pick someone up (one of my favorites).Automatically locks the door and turns off when you walk away from the car.Displays warnings when any passenger (not just the person in the passenger seat) does not have their seatbelt on.Displays speed limit on the touchscreen, though it’s sometimes off by 5 or 10 mph.Allows you to record video from its cameras if a USB is plugged in.Shakes the steering wheel if you drift out of the lane without signaling.Pushing the brake with force will let you set the car on “Hold” so you don’t have to keep your foot on the brake. Overall, the Model 3 is a really nice car with some super convenient features, though there are some minor errors in displaying the speed limit and over-ther-air updates. I’d highly recommend this car if you’re a big fan of having the most cutting-edge technology available. For others, I’d recommend it if you’re looking for a car that looks good and has convenience features.
title: I recently got a Tesla — these are my first thoughts.
content_html:
I recently got a Tesla — these are my first thoughts.

Jerry Wei
Apr 1

Teslas are known for being technologically sophisticated, along with being one of the most recognizable electric cars out there.

I’m a tech-savvy guy, and so I got the Mid-Range Tesla Model 3 with Enhanced Autopilot. Here’s what I think about it.

Delivery. In my opinion, one of the coolest things about buying a Tesla is seeing it pull up to your house. It’s a really sleek car, and it’s soooo quiet (I thought I had gone deaf!). The lack of an engine really goes a long way and makes it so much cooler as it rolls in. The delivery went smoothly; a Tesla sales representative helped me out with getting to know the car.

Looks. Honestly, this car looks so nice. The panoramic glass roof with UV protection is gorgeous, the hidden door handles are subtle touches, the wheels are pretty cool, and the curved design is beautiful. 10/10.

Regenerative braking. One of the more difficult elements to get used to is the regenerative braking. Teslas use this feature to regenerate some battery using the momentum of your car. Essentially, when you let go of the accelerator, the car slows down as if you had lightly hit the brakes. At first, I thought this was a super weird feature, and it was definitely hard to get used to. When I got used to it though, it turns out it’s really convenient. Regenerative braking lets you use one pedal to drive, and it really goes easy on your legs. Definitely one of my favorite features.

Autopilot. Some people don’t get enhanced autopilot on their Teslas, which doesn’t really make sense to me since that’s one of the most defining aspects of Teslas. Anyway, this feature is super cool and really good at making commutes less annoying. I love driving, but traffic annoys even me! Activating Autopilot in traffic for some reason makes it such a better drive — you don’t have to think too hard about accelerating and braking every 3 seconds because the Tesla does it for you. Protects your sanity. In terms of using it in non-traffic scenarios, I find that it brakes a little later than I like. That being said, it never rear-ends another car, so maybe I just like braking early.

Sensors and Cameras. Teslas sport a huge array of cameras and sensors and displays the information for you on the screen. It detects lanes, shows the cars around you, and can record crashes. This lets it have Forward Collision Warning, where it beeps if you’re approaching a car in front of you very quickly. It also has Automatic Emergency Braking as a final resort, braking hard to try to avoid rear-ending someone. I haven’t had to use Automatic Emergency Braking yet, and there haven’t been any real cases where I need Forward Collision Warning, but it has activated when I’ve gotten close to parked car in my neighborhood (that I wasn’t going to hit on my current path).

Tesla App. This is an awesome design. As I said, I’m a tech-savvy guy, so being able to control a car with my phone is unbelievable. I can control the music, lock/unlock the car, turn on/off the climate, and so much more all from my phone! The app also allows for keyless driving, or you can set up your phone to be a key. No more forgetting your key and having to run back to grab it.

Over-the-air Software Updates. This is another really nice feature of the Tesla. Instead of having to get a new car to get the new features, Teslas just download the features when connected to Wi-Fi. So this definitely cool in theory, but I’m having trouble getting software updates — I received the Sentry Mode update about a month after it started being released, and I haven’t gotten any of the more recent updates yet. Adding a button to manually check for updates would be something that Tesla can look into.

Quality-Of-Life Features. There are a variety of other fantastic details that make life so much easier for me. Here are just some of the cool features:

  • Automatically opens your garage door when you get leave or approach your house.
  • Driver profiles — Teslas automatically move the seat back to easily let you inside and it’s quite easy to select and change a driver profile.
  • Will look in the blind spot for you when you try to make a lane change; the lane will appear red on the screen if there’s a car there.
  • Automatic windshield wipers will adjust speed based on how heavy the precipitation is.
  • Automatic high-beam lights will turn on high-beam for you.
  • Sentry Mode monitors your car when it’s parked and records anyone who damages it, though you have to manually turn it on every time.
  • Automatic parking brakes will set the parking brake for you when you park and disengage it when you move.
  • Allows you to play Atari on the touchscreen when you’re waiting to pick someone up (one of my favorites).
  • Automatically locks the door and turns off when you walk away from the car.
  • Displays warnings when any passenger (not just the person in the passenger seat) does not have their seatbelt on.
  • Displays speed limit on the touchscreen, though it’s sometimes off by 5 or 10 mph.
  • Allows you to record video from its cameras if a USB is plugged in.
  • Shakes the steering wheel if you drift out of the lane without signaling.
  • Pushing the brake with force will let you set the car on “Hold” so you don’t have to keep your foot on the brake.

Overall, the Model 3 is a really nice car with some super convenient features, though there are some minor errors in displaying the speed limit and over-ther-air updates. I’d highly recommend this car if you’re a big fan of having the most cutting-edge technology available. For others, I’d recommend it if you’re looking for a car that looks good and has convenience features.

I recently got a Tesla — these are my first thoughts.

Jerry Wei
Apr 1

Teslas are known for being technologically sophisticated, along with being one of the most recognizable electric cars out there.

I’m a tech-savvy guy, and so I got the Mid-Range Tesla Model 3 with Enhanced Autopilot. Here’s what I think about it.

Delivery. In my opinion, one of the coolest things about buying a Tesla is seeing it pull up to your house. It’s a really sleek car, and it’s soooo quiet (I thought I had gone deaf!). The lack of an engine really goes a long way and makes it so much cooler as it rolls in. The delivery went smoothly; a Tesla sales representative helped me out with getting to know the car.

Looks. Honestly, this car looks so nice. The panoramic glass roof with UV protection is gorgeous, the hidden door handles are subtle touches, the wheels are pretty cool, and the curved design is beautiful. 10/10.

Regenerative braking. One of the more difficult elements to get used to is the regenerative braking. Teslas use this feature to regenerate some battery using the momentum of your car. Essentially, when you let go of the accelerator, the car slows down as if you had lightly hit the brakes. At first, I thought this was a super weird feature, and it was definitely hard to get used to. When I got used to it though, it turns out it’s really convenient. Regenerative braking lets you use one pedal to drive, and it really goes easy on your legs. Definitely one of my favorite features.

Autopilot. Some people don’t get enhanced autopilot on their Teslas, which doesn’t really make sense to me since that’s one of the most defining aspects of Teslas. Anyway, this feature is super cool and really good at making commutes less annoying. I love driving, but traffic annoys even me! Activating Autopilot in traffic for some reason makes it such a better drive — you don’t have to think too hard about accelerating and braking every 3 seconds because the Tesla does it for you. Protects your sanity. In terms of using it in non-traffic scenarios, I find that it brakes a little later than I like. That being said, it never rear-ends another car, so maybe I just like braking early.

Sensors and Cameras. Teslas sport a huge array of cameras and sensors and displays the information for you on the screen. It detects lanes, shows the cars around you, and can record crashes. This lets it have Forward Collision Warning, where it beeps if you’re approaching a car in front of you very quickly. It also has Automatic Emergency Braking as a final resort, braking hard to try to avoid rear-ending someone. I haven’t had to use Automatic Emergency Braking yet, and there haven’t been any real cases where I need Forward Collision Warning, but it has activated when I’ve gotten close to parked car in my neighborhood (that I wasn’t going to hit on my current path).

Tesla App. This is an awesome design. As I said, I’m a tech-savvy guy, so being able to control a car with my phone is unbelievable. I can control the music, lock/unlock the car, turn on/off the climate, and so much more all from my phone! The app also allows for keyless driving, or you can set up your phone to be a key. No more forgetting your key and having to run back to grab it.

Over-the-air Software Updates. This is another really nice feature of the Tesla. Instead of having to get a new car to get the new features, Teslas just download the features when connected to Wi-Fi. So this definitely cool in theory, but I’m having trouble getting software updates — I received the Sentry Mode update about a month after it started being released, and I haven’t gotten any of the more recent updates yet. Adding a button to manually check for updates would be something that Tesla can look into.

Quality-Of-Life Features. There are a variety of other fantastic details that make life so much easier for me. Here are just some of the cool features:

  • Automatically opens your garage door when you get leave or approach your house.
  • Driver profiles — Teslas automatically move the seat back to easily let you inside and it’s quite easy to select and change a driver profile.
  • Will look in the blind spot for you when you try to make a lane change; the lane will appear red on the screen if there’s a car there.
  • Automatic windshield wipers will adjust speed based on how heavy the precipitation is.
  • Automatic high-beam lights will turn on high-beam for you.
  • Sentry Mode monitors your car when it’s parked and records anyone who damages it, though you have to manually turn it on every time.
  • Automatic parking brakes will set the parking brake for you when you park and disengage it when you move.
  • Allows you to play Atari on the touchscreen when you’re waiting to pick someone up (one of my favorites).
  • Automatically locks the door and turns off when you walk away from the car.
  • Displays warnings when any passenger (not just the person in the passenger seat) does not have their seatbelt on.
  • Displays speed limit on the touchscreen, though it’s sometimes off by 5 or 10 mph.
  • Allows you to record video from its cameras if a USB is plugged in.
  • Shakes the steering wheel if you drift out of the lane without signaling.
  • Pushing the brake with force will let you set the car on “Hold” so you don’t have to keep your foot on the brake.

Overall, the Model 3 is a really nice car with some super convenient features, though there are some minor errors in displaying the speed limit and over-ther-air updates. I’d highly recommend this car if you’re a big fan of having the most cutting-edge technology available. For others, I’d recommend it if you’re looking for a car that looks good and has convenience features.
